contentrichtext.text: [[File:Evelyn Barbara Balfour.jpg|thumb|right|Balfour in 1943]] '''Lady Evelyn Barbara "Eve" Balfour''' (1899-1990) was an [[England|English]] farmer, educator, [[organic farming]] pioneer, and a founding figure in the [[organic movement]]. She was one of the first women to study agriculture at an English university, graduating from the [[University of Reading]]. The daughter of the [[Gerald Balfour, 2nd Earl of Balfour|second Earl of Balfour]], she began farming in 1920, in [[Haughley Green]], [[Suffolk]], [[England]]. In 1939, with her friend and neighbor Ryan Nelson, she launched the [[Haughley Experiment]], the first long-term, side-by-side [[scientific]] comparison of organic and [[conventional agriculture|chemical-based farming]]. In 1943, she published the organics classic, ''[[The Living Soil]]'', a book combining her research with the initial findings at Haughley. She then started a series of lectures and talks based around farmers markets and cattle sales, often joined in [[Wales]] by Dinah Williams, who founded the first organic dairy farm that today is the feed farm for [[Rachel's Organic]] [[dairy produce]].<ref name=Times6847838>{{cite news | title=The Soil Association | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article6847838.ece | work=The Times | location=London | date=2009-09-25 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> In 1946, she co-founded and became the first president of the [[Soil Association]], an international organization claiming to promote [[sustainable agriculture]] (and the main [[organic farming]] association in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] today). She continued to farm, write and lecture for the rest of her life, including a year-long tour throughout [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] during which she met Australian organic farming pioneers including Henry Shoobridge, president of the [[Living Soil Association of Tasmania]] which was the first association to affiliate with the [[Soil Association]].<ref>Paull, John (2011) [http://ora.ouls.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid%3A8ec8fe88-d33a-4205-b1cd-2d48a32cba71/datastreams/ATTACHMENT01 "The Soil Association and Australia: From Mother Earth to Eve Balfour"], Mother Earth, v.4 (Spring): 13-17.</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ladyevebalfour.org/ Website dedicated to Lady Eve Balfour, accessed 28 December 2010] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/womanshour/timeline/eve_balfour.shtml BBC biography page, accessed 28 December 2010] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Balfour, Lady Eve | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1899 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1990 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balfour, Lady Eve}} [[Category:People from Suffolk]] [[Category:Daughters of British earls]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Reading]] [[Category:English farmers]] [[Category:English environmentalists]] [[Category:Non-fiction environmental writers]] [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]]
